The system is designed to support green mobility in Oman and offers an alternative to traditional methods of hydrogen production. The project aims to leverage abundant solar and seawater resources to enable large-scale hydrogen production without competing for land or freshwater.
key_takeaways: The simulated off-grid floating PV-desalination system consists of 32,050 photovoltaic panels, a pumping system, a seawater reverse-osmosis desalination unit, an electrolyzer, and a hydrogen storage tank.
The system has the potential to achieve a levelized cost of electricity of $0.05/kWh and a levelized cost of hydrogen of $9.5/kg, making it a viable alternative for green mobility in Oman.
The project aims to reduce competition for land and freshwater resources by leveraging abundant solar and seawater resources, offering a sustainable solution for large-scale hydrogen production.

articles.title: ERCOT Again Revising Large Load Interconnection Process
articles.summary: ERCOT, the regional transmission organization for Texas, has proposed revisions to its large load interconnection process due to increasing demand from power-hungry facilities such as data centers and bitcoin miners. The current process is outdated and lacks clarity, leading to a backlog of over 269% more requests for interconnection in 2026 compared to 2024. ERCOT is seeking additional changes to manage the growing load, which will require developing new infrastructure.
key_takeaways: ERCOT has experienced a significant increase in large load interconnection requests, with 63 GW of requests at the end of 2024 and over 233 GW in queue for 2026, representing a 269% increase.
The majority of these requests come from data centers, accounting for about 77% of the total load, highlighting the growing demand for power from these facilities.

ERCOT has approved extra-high voltage transmission projects to serve large loads, but completion is expected in the 2030s, emphasizing the need for additional changes to manage the growing energy demands.

articles.title: Maryland’s largest solar farm is now online on a former coal mine
articles.summary: Maryland's largest solar farm, built on a former coal mine in western Maryland, is now online and generating clean electricity. This project marks a significant milestone in the state's transition to renewable energy sources. The solar farm was developed by Competitive Power Ventures (CPV).
key_takeaways: Maryland has become home to its largest solar farm, which was built on a former coal mine.
The project is part of the state's efforts to transition away from fossil fuels and towards cleaner, more sustainable energy sources.
By repurposing former coal mine land as a source of renewable energy, the project helps to reduce environmental impact and promote economic development in the region.

articles.title: Maine PUC Issues Multistate Transmission, Generation Procurement
articles.summary: The Maine Public Utilities Commission (PUC) has issued a request for proposals (RFP) to procure clean energy in Northern Maine and 1,200 MW of transmission to connect it to the ISO-New England (ISO-NE) grid. This move aims to address the lack of transmission in the region, which is part of the Eastern Interconnection through New Brunswick, but not directly connected to ISO-NE. The RFP is complementary to ISO-NE's first Longer-term Transmission Planning (LTTP) procurement and is contingent on the success of that procurement.
key_takeaways: The Maine PUC has issued an RFP to procure clean energy in Northern Maine and 1,200 MW of transmission to connect it to the ISO-NE grid, addressing a significant barrier to clean energy growth in the region.

The RFP is complementary to ISO-NE's LTTP procurement and requires the transmission proposals to connect to the RTO at the northern terminus of facilities constructed as part of the LTTP solicitation.
The project bidders can submit standalone transactions or join with existing projects, and the RFP aims to support the development of onshore wind in Northern Maine.

articles.title: Policy storms ahead, fire safety and data centres: Energy-Storage.news 2025 Guest Blog picks, Part 1
articles.summary: The article is a collection of guest blog contributions from Energy Storage News, covering various topics related to power and energy systems. The articles cover policy storms ahead, fire safety in data centers, and other relevant topics as part of the publication's efforts to provide insights on emerging trends in the industry.
key_takeaways: Policy storms are expected to impact the energy storage industry, with regulatory changes and incentives potentially influencing market demand.
Fire safety is a growing concern for data centers, which require specialized cooling systems to prevent overheating and potential fires.
Emerging technologies, such as advanced batteries and power electronics, are driving innovation in the energy storage sector.

articles.title: Why Kansas could be at a turning point on solar
articles.summary: Kansas is considered a prime location for solar energy due to its sunny weather and flat landscape, yet it lags behind other states in terms of solar installations. The early adoption of wind energy on the Great Plains has overshadowed solar energy development in Kansas. This disparity raises questions about why solar hasn't gained more traction in the state.
key_takeaways: Kansas's unique geography makes it an ideal location for large-scale solar panel installations, but the state's relatively low ranking in terms of solar installations suggests that other factors are at play.

The early dominance of wind energy on the Great Plains has likely contributed to a lack of focus on solar energy development in Kansas, as investors and policymakers may have prioritized wind as a more established source of renewable energy.

Despite its sunny weather and favorable geography, Kansas still ranks relatively low among states in terms of solar installations, suggesting that a combination of factors, including policy support, infrastructure, and market demand, is needed to drive the growth of the solar industry in the state.

articles.title: Idaho Power Can Retain Market-based Rate Authority, FERC Rules
articles.summary: Idaho Power has been allowed to retain its market-based rate authority (MBRA) after acquiring additional resources in 2023 and 2024. FERC ruled that the utility's own market power analysis showed it still passed wholesale market share screens for WEIM and adjacent first-tier markets, but failed screens in its own balancing authority area. The decision came after Idaho Power submitted change in status notices to report new resource additions.
key_takeaways: Idaho Power has been allowed to retain its MBRA after acquiring over 200 MW of resources in 2023 and 2024.
FERC ruled that the utility's market power analysis showed it passed wholesale market share screens for WEIM and adjacent first-tier markets, but failed screens in its own balancing authority area.
The decision comes after Idaho Power submitted change in status notices to report new resource additions, including two solar facilities and an expanded battery storage facility.

articles.title: SK Eternix Launches 40MW Solid Oxide Fuel Cell Plant at Chungju Eco Park
articles.summary: SK Eternix has launched a 40MW solid oxide fuel cell (SOFC) power plant at Chungju Eco Park in South Korea, marking the company's first large-scale SOFC deployment. The plant uses high-temperature chemistry to generate electricity, heat, and water, with overall efficiency reaching 60-70%. This technology is expected to play a significant role in Korea's transition to a hydrogen economy.
key_takeaways: SK Eternix has launched a 40MW solid oxide fuel cell (SOFC) power plant at Chungju Eco Park, showcasing the company's first large-scale SOFC deployment in South Korea.
The SOFC technology uses high-temperature chemistry to generate electricity, heat, and water with an overall efficiency of 60-70%, making it a more efficient alternative to conventional gas turbines.

The plant is part of SK Eternix's clean-energy playbook, which also includes solar, wind, and energy storage solutions, highlighting the company's commitment to renewable energy and reducing reliance on fossil fuels.

articles.title: Solar glare forces panel removal at Amsterdam Airport
articles.summary: The Amsterdam Airport Schiphol was forced to temporarily close its runway due to solar glare from a nearby solar park, prompting the removal of approximately 78,000 PV modules. The incident highlighted the challenges posed by solar panels in areas with high sunlight exposure. A solution was eventually identified, involving the removal and replacement of affected panels.
key_takeaways: The solar panel installation at Amsterdam Airport Schiphol caused glare that impaired pilots' visibility when the sun was shining, prompting temporary runway closures.
The Dutch authorities ordered the removal of about 78,000 PV modules from two fields of the solar park to prevent further disruptions and reduce the risk of accidents.

A solution was implemented involving the removal of affected panels and applying anti-reflective film to others, with the majority of the removed panels being redeployed in new projects where glare is not a concern.

articles.title: Organizations Celebrate NTEC Fossil Gas Plant Hitting Major Setback, Groups Call on Dairyland Power Coop to Cancel Plans
articles.summary: The Nemadji Trail Energy Center (NTEC) fossil gas plant project, proposed by Dairyland Power Cooperative and Basin Electric Power Cooperative, has hit a major setback with Minnesota Power's decision to withdraw from the project. This development has been welcomed by organizations opposing the project. Groups are now calling on Dairyland Power Cooperative to cancel its plans for the NTEC gas plant.
key_takeaways: The Nemadji Trail Energy Center (NTEC) fossil gas plant project, a proposed energy facility in Wisconsin, has encountered a significant setback with Minnesota Power's withdrawal from the project.
This development is seen as a positive step by organizations opposed to the project, which aims to construct a gas-fired power plant using natural gas from the Bakken shale formation.

Dairyland Power Cooperative is now under pressure from groups to cancel its plans for the NTEC gas plant, with these groups likely hoping to prevent the construction of this new fossil fuel-based energy facility.

articles.title: Green Hydrogen Production Takes Off at Fortum’s Kalla Test Center
articles.summary: Fortum has successfully produced its first batch of green hydrogen at the Kalla Test Center in Finland, marking a significant milestone in their efforts to speed up electrification and decarbonize industries. The €17 million pilot project is part of Fortum's larger push to produce low-carbon energy and aims to crack open new routes for hard-to-abate sectors like steel, chemicals, and shipping. The project involves several partners who have installed advanced electrolyser technologies to split water into hydrogen and oxygen.
key_takeaways: Fortum has partnered with multiple companies, including Stargate Hydrogen, Hystar, and Valmet Automation Inc, to install two advanced electrolysers at the Kalla Test Center, aiming to drive down costs and boost performance.
The project's modular design allows partners to swap components or test new electrode coatings as they mature, making it an innovative approach to hydrogen production.

Fortum's P2X Solutions platform aims to produce hydrogen at prices that can rival fossil-derived alternatives, marking a significant step towards decarbonizing industries where electrification is not possible.

articles.title: Modular Landfill Remediation for AI Grid Resilience
articles.summary: The article proposes a modular landfill remediation framework to address the dual challenges of rising AI electricity demand and persistent landfill methane emissions in the US. The proposed system integrates excavation, screening, and behind-the-meter combined heat and power to transform environmental liabilities into resilience assets. This approach aims to mitigate site-level methane by 60-70% and recover urban land while supplying firm islandable power.
key_takeaways: The proposed modular landfill remediation framework can mitigate site-level methane emissions by 60-70% and supply approximately 20 MW of firm, islandable power.
Treating legacy landfill sites as stock resources can transform environmental liabilities into resilience assets, providing critical microgrid resilience and black-start capability.
The approach aims to resolve long-term environmental liabilities by valuing remediation-oriented waste-to-energy as a strategic control volume for buffering critical loads against grid volatility.

articles.title: Finite-sample guarantees for data-driven forward-backward operator methods
articles.summary: The article discusses finite-sample guarantees for data-driven forward-backward operator methods, specifically focusing on algorithmic stability and the quality of solutions produced by these methods. It establishes probabilistic bounds on the distance between a true zero and the output of the method without making specific assumptions about the underlying data distribution. The results are applied to a popular stochastic Nash equilibrium seeking algorithm and validated on a control problem for smart grids.
key_takeaways: The article provides finite-sample guarantees for data-driven forward-backward operator methods, which is an improvement over previous works that made assumptions about the data distribution.
Algorithmic stability bounds grow proportionally to the number of iterations if weaker conditions are met, but become independent of iteration count under stronger assumptions.
The results are specialized to a popular stochastic Nash equilibrium seeking algorithm and validated on a control problem for smart grids, demonstrating their practical applicability.

articles.title: Alphabet Buying Clean Energy Developer to Support Data Centers
articles.summary: Alphabet, the parent company of Google, has agreed to acquire Intersect, a clean energy developer that provides data center and energy infrastructure solutions, for $4.75 billion in cash and debt assumption.
key_takeaways: Alphabet is acquiring Intersect to support its growing data center operations and expand its clean energy capabilities.
The acquisition marks a significant investment in the clean energy sector by Alphabet, further emphasizing its commitment to sustainability.
As part of the deal, Google already owns a minority stake in Intersect, indicating that the company has been involved with the developer for some time.

articles.title: Interior Dept cuts 400k homes’ electricity just before Christmas, raising prices
articles.summary: The Interior Department has illegally paused five wind power projects in the Atlantic, including one that was providing electricity to 400,000 homes in Massachusetts. This pause occurred just before Christmas and during a time when electricity prices have already increased compared to previous years. The move is expected to raise energy prices for households.
key_takeaways: The Interior Department's actions have resulted in the pause of five wind power projects, including one that was providing cheap electricity to 400,000 homes in Massachusetts.
The timing of the pause, just before Christmas and during a holiday season with already increased electricity prices, is likely to exacerbate energy price increases for households.
The illegality of the Interior Department's actions raises concerns about the department's role in undermining renewable energy projects and increasing reliance on fossil fuels.

articles.title: The Hydrogen Stream: CMB.Tech secures China green ammonia offtake
articles.summary: CMB.Tech has secured an offtake agreement for renewable ammonia from CEEC Hydrogen Energy's 800 MW wind-and-solar-powered project in China, marking the world's largest green hydrogen, ammonia, and methanol project. Meanwhile, Gascade Gastransport has converted approximately 400 km of gas pipelines in Germany to form a new hydrogen transport corridor. These developments demonstrate growing efforts to establish large-scale renewable energy projects and hydrogen infrastructure.
key_takeaways: CMB.Tech has secured an offtake agreement for green ammonia from CEEC Hydrogen Energy's project in China, which will own a minority share in the privately owned Jiangsu Andefu company.
The CEEC Songyuan project is the world's largest green hydrogen, ammonia, and methanol project, with an annual production capacity of approximately 158,000 tonnes of renewable ammonia.
Gascade Gastransport has converted about 400 km of gas pipelines in Germany to form a new hydrogen transport corridor, establishing a key part of the German hydrogen core network.

articles.title: Zambia Wants To Add 2.3MW Of Solar Coupled With A 4.16MWh Battery To Each One Of The Country’s 156 Constituencies
articles.summary: Zambia aims to increase renewable energy integration by adding solar power and a battery storage system to each of its 156 constituencies, building on the country's existing high reliance on renewables. The proposed expansion seeks to further reduce the grid's dependence on hydroelectric power. This initiative could contribute to increased energy efficiency and reduced greenhouse gas emissions.
key_takeaways: Zambia plans to add 2.3MW of solar power coupled with a 4.16MWh battery storage system to each constituency, covering 156 locations across the country.
The proposal aims to further diversify the country's renewable energy mix, reducing its reliance on hydroelectric power and increasing overall reliance on renewables.
This initiative could lead to improved energy efficiency and reduced greenhouse gas emissions in Zambia by promoting distributed solar and energy storage solutions.

articles.title: Irish solar rises in 2025 as government plans €18.9 billion of grid upgrades
articles.summary:
**SUMMARY**
Ireland's renewable energy sector is experiencing significant growth, with solar power being a key contributor. The country has set an ambitious plan to increase the supply of onshore wind and solar electricity by 2030, backed by a €18.9 billion investment package. This growth is reflected in provisional data showing a notable increase in monthly utility-scale solar generation in the first nine months of 2025.

**KEY TAKEAWAYS**

* Ireland's monthly utility-scale solar generation increased from an average of 0.73 TWh in 2024 to 0.99 TWh in the first nine months of 2025, indicating a notable growth in the country's renewable energy sector.
* The government has invested €18.9 billion ($22.2 billion) in a grid upgrade plan, which includes increasing the supply of onshore wind and solar electricity by 2030.
* Ireland has made significant progress in its renewable energy transition, with rooftop solar capacity reaching 1 GW and total solar PV generation in 2024 standing at 1.09 TWh.

articles.title: BYD surpasses 1.5 million residential storage systems worldwide
articles.summary: BYD has reached a milestone of installing over 1.5 million residential energy storage systems worldwide, driven by its BatteryBox brand. This achievement marks 10 years of effort in the residential and small commercial energy storage market for BYD. The company claims to be one of the most widely adopted distributed energy storage solutions globally.
key_takeaways: BYD has surpassed 1.5 million global installations of its BatteryBox residential energy storage systems, indicating significant growth since June 2024.
This milestone reflects 10 years of effort by BYD in the residential and small commercial energy storage market, solidifying its position as a leading distributed energy storage solution.
The company's success with BatteryBox suggests widespread adoption of its technology globally, without specifying which regions have been most prominent.

articles.title: US battery market faces make-or-break year in 2026
articles.summary: The US battery market is facing intense pressure heading into 2026, driven by rising demand for energy storage due to AI and data center-driven electricity demand, record-high electricity prices, shifting battery costs, and new policies. These factors are pushing the sector towards a "make-or-break" year, where companies must adapt to changing market conditions to remain competitive. The industry is expected to undergo significant changes in 2026.
key_takeaways: Rising AI and data center-driven energy demand is significantly increasing electricity demand, creating pressure on the battery market.
Shifting battery costs are unevenly impacting the sector, with project economics under strain due to these cost fluctuations.
New policies set to come into effect in 2026 will likely cause further shake-ups in the industry, adding to the existing pressures.

articles.title: What the Western REC registry shake-up means for corporate clean energy
articles.summary: The Western Renewable Energy Generation Information System is undergoing a shake-up, which may create near-term uncertainties and risks for corporate clean energy. This change could impact the industry's ability to accurately track renewable energy production and sales. The consequences of this shake-up are still unclear.
key_takeaways: The Western REC registry shake-up poses significant challenges for tracking renewable energy production and sales in the region.
Near-term uncertainties may arise from the rebuilding process, potentially affecting corporate clean energy strategies and investments.
The impact of this change on the industry's ability to accurately report and manage renewable energy credits (RECs) is still unknown.

articles.title: FERC Rejects Complaint over SPP’s Accreditation Practices
articles.summary: The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) has dismissed a complaint filed by public interest organizations against SPP's accreditation practices for thermal and renewable resources. The complaint, which was filed in April 2024, alleged that SPP's methods were unjust, unreasonable, unduly discriminatory, or preferential. However, FERC ruled that its approval of SPP's new resource accreditation framework in July made the complaint's target "no longer effective".
key_takeaways: FERC dismissed a complaint against SPP's accreditation practices for thermal and renewable resources due to changes made to the company's methodologies.
The original methods were criticized for being unjust, unreasonable, unduly discriminatory, or preferential, but FERC cited its recent approval of new methodologies as rendering the complaint moot.
The complaint was filed under sections 206 and 306 of the Federal Power Act by organizations such as the Sierra Club, Natural Resources Defense Council, and Sustainable FERC Project.

articles.title: Japan Prepares to Restart Unit at World’s Largest Nuclear Power Plant
articles.summary: The Kashiwazaki-Kariwa nuclear power plant in Japan has been given approval to restart a reactor unit, marking a significant step towards the country's nuclear energy revival. The facility, which is currently idle due to the Fukushima nuclear disaster, has sat dormant since 2012 and holds nearly 8,000 MW of total generation capacity. This move may signal a shift away from Japan's reliance on nuclear power.
key_takeaways: Local government officials in Japan have approved the restart of a reactor unit at the Kashiwazaki-Kariwa facility, which is currently one of the largest nuclear power plants in the world.
The restart comes nearly 12 years after the Fukushima nuclear disaster in 2011, which led to Japan's nuclear power industry being largely shut down.
The decision marks a significant step towards reviving Japan's nuclear energy sector and demonstrates the country's willingness to reconsider its reliance on nuclear power.

articles.title: Home energy upgrades you’ll regret not doing while installing rooftop solar
articles.summary: The article highlights the benefits of upgrading home energy systems while installing rooftop solar arrays to save costs in the long run. These upgrades can range from upgrading panels to adding energy-efficient features like insulation and smart home technology. By doing so, homeowners can reap significant financial and environmental rewards.
key_takeaways: Upgrading to high-efficiency solar panels during installation can be significantly cheaper than replacing them later.
Adding insulation and weatherstripping while installing a rooftop solar system can help reduce heat loss and energy bills.
Integrating smart home technology, such as smart thermostats or energy monitoring systems, into the installation process can enhance the overall efficiency and comfort of the home.

articles.title: Bulgarian Group Has Deal to Build Up to Six BWRX-300 SMRs
articles.summary: A Bulgarian energy company, Blue Bird Energy AD, has partnered with a European project developer to form a joint venture that aims to deploy up to six Small Modular Reactors (SMRs) in the country. The SMRs will be built using the BWRX-300 design from GE Vernova Hitachi Nuclear Energy. This development could potentially increase Bulgaria's nuclear energy capacity.
key_takeaways: A Bulgarian company, Blue Bird Energy AD, has partnered with SGE S.A. to form a joint venture for building up to six Small Modular Reactors (SMRs) in the country.
The SMRs will be designed by GE Vernova Hitachi Nuclear Energy using their BWRX-300 technology.
This partnership could potentially increase Bulgaria's nuclear energy capacity, as it plans to deploy up to six reactors.

articles.title: Dutch regulator finds grid fees for rooftop solar are reasonable
articles.summary:
**SUMMARY**
The Dutch competition regulator, Authority for Consumers and Markets (ACM), has determined that grid fees for rooftop solar installations in the Netherlands are reasonable. The regulator has found that energy suppliers charge feed-in costs uniformly, making it easier for consumers to compare contracts. This decision is consistent with previous investigations by ACM, which also ruled that fees were reasonable.

**KEY TAKEAWAYS**

* The Dutch regulator has concluded that grid fees for rooftop solar installations in the Netherlands are not unreasonably high.
* Energy suppliers in the Netherlands charge feed-in costs uniformly, making it easier for consumers to compare contracts and choose a plan that suits their needs.
* This decision is consistent with previous investigations by ACM, which also ruled that fees were reasonable due to the costs incurred by energy suppliers when feeding solar power back into the grid.

articles.title: Trump admin ‘pauses’ leases for five offshore wind projects already under construction
articles.summary: The US Department of the Interior has paused leases for five large-scale offshore wind projects under construction due to "national security risks" identified by the Department of War. The Trump administration claims that the movement of blade tips and reflective towers create radar interference, posing a threat to national security. These paused projects include several high-profile offshore wind farms.
key_takeaways: The US government has paused leases for five large-scale offshore wind projects under construction due to perceived national security risks.
The Department of War identified potential vulnerabilities in these projects, citing radar interference as a concern caused by the movement of blade tips and reflective towers.

The paused projects include several high-profile offshore wind farms, including the Coastal Virginia Offshore Wind project, which was criticized for threatening grid reliability and leading to energy inflation.

articles.title: AI tool can simulate complex fusion plasma in seconds
articles.summary: A team of scientists has developed an AI tool called GyroSwin that can simulate complex fusion plasma at speeds up to 1,000 times faster than traditional computational methods, making it a significant breakthrough in the field of nuclear energy.
key_takeaways: The AI tool GyroSwin allows for simulations of complex fusion plasma, which is crucial for advancing nuclear energy technologies.
The new method is significantly faster than traditional computational approaches, potentially accelerating research and development in the field.
The collaboration between UK Atomic Energy Authority, Johannes Kepler University Linz, and Emmi AI demonstrates the potential for interdisciplinary partnerships to drive innovation.

articles.title: Can US trade policy deliver a domestic battery supply chain?
articles.summary: The article discusses the importance of building a domestic battery supply chain in the US, citing that limiting foreign participation is not enough to achieve this goal. A strong and diverse domestic energy storage manufacturing capacity is necessary to support US trade policy objectives. Aaron Marks argues that more needs to be done beyond just restricting foreign involvement.
key_takeaways: The article emphasizes that a domestic battery supply chain in the US requires a comprehensive approach, involving not only limiting foreign participation but also investments in domestic manufacturing infrastructure and research.
A lack of transparency and standardization in energy storage regulations hinders the development of a robust domestic industry, making it difficult to attract investment and talent.

Aaron Marks suggests that the US government needs to create incentives for domestic companies to invest in battery production, such as tax breaks or subsidies, to support the growth of this critical sector.

articles.title: Using horizontally connected salt caverns for compressed air storage
articles.summary: Researchers in China have investigated the long-term stability of using horizontally connected salt caverns for compressed air energy storage. They found that approximately 85% of existing salt caverns in their country are suitable for this configuration, particularly those with low-grade inclined salt layers. The study aims to identify the optimal conditions for such caverns, which are becoming increasingly scarce due to expanding reservoirs.
key_takeaways: Approximately 85% of existing salt caverns in China are suitable for horizontally connected storage, primarily those with low-grade inclined salt layers.
Researchers investigated the effects of burial depth and dip angle on the stability of these caverns, aiming to identify optimal conditions for compressed air energy storage.
The study highlights the importance of exploring alternative storage configurations, as high-quality caverns with favorable geological conditions are becoming increasingly scarce.

articles.title: Australian utility Flow Power closes financing on its first BESS project, in Victoria’s Latrobe Valley
articles.summary: Flow Power has successfully closed financing on its first battery storage project (BESS) in Victoria's Latrobe Valley, Australia, which will provide 100MW of power and 223MWh of energy storage capacity.
key_takeaways: The project is the first BESS initiative from renewable energy generator and retailer Flow Power, indicating a significant investment in the company's growth strategy.
A 100MW/223MWh battery storage facility in Latrobe Valley suggests that Flow Power aims to stabilize the grid during periods of high renewable energy production and ensure reliability in the region.
The location in Victoria, Australia, highlights the importance of regional grid stability and the need for advanced energy storage solutions to support the integration of renewable energy sources.

articles.title: Scaling Hydrogen Production to Power California’s Data Centers
articles.summary: A partnership between Vema Hydrogen and Verne has been formed to deliver clean, reliable hydrogen to power California's data centers. The agreement aims to address the growing energy demands of AI-driven projects by leveraging a new method of producing hydrogen called Engineered Mineral Hydrogen (EMH). This approach bypasses traditional hydrogen production methods and utilizes geoscience wizardry to produce hydrogen on a massive scale.
key_takeaways: Verne plans to fuel its on-site power and cooling systems with over 36,000 metric tons of clean hydrogen per year, starting as early as 2028.
The partnership uses Engineered Mineral Hydrogen (EMH), which relies on geoscience wizardry to produce hydrogen from the rocks in gigawatt-scale quantities.
EMH tackles two major challenges in traditional hydrogen production methods: massive scale and unpredictability, making it an attractive solution for securing massive volumes of clean energy.

articles.title: Mexico approves 2.4 GW of solar projects
articles.summary: Mexico's energy ministry has approved 20 new renewable energy projects, with 15 being solar, adding up to 3,320 MW of installed capacity. This follows an October decree that regulated private sector investments in the country's energy sector. The announcement signals a shift towards reactivating the energy sector after a six-year period of paralysis.
key_takeaways: Mexico has approved 20 new renewable energy projects, with 15 being solar, totaling 2,471 MW of installed capacity.
The remaining five projects are wind farms that will add an additional 894 MW to the national electricity system.
According to a preliminary schedule, 19% of the newly-announced projects are planned for operational completion in 2027, with the majority (78%) set to become operational by 2028.

articles.title: Green Hydrogen-Based E-Fuels to Power Hapag-Lloyd and NCL’s Container Ships from 2027
articles.summary: The Zero Emission Maritime Buyers Alliance (ZEMBA) has announced that Hapag-Lloyd and North Sea Container Line (NCL) will power their container ships with green hydrogen-based e-fuels starting in 2027. The two companies have committed to using e-methanol and e-ammonia, which are produced from hydrogen via electrolysis powered by renewables. This marks a significant step towards industrial decarbonization and scaling up zero-emission technology.
key_takeaways: Hapag-Lloyd and NCL will power their container ships with green hydrogen-based e-fuels starting in 2027, marking the first multi-year commitment of its kind.
The companies will use approximately 70,000 metric tons of e-methanol and 25,000 tons of e-ammonia per year, which is expected to cut nearly 95,000 metric tons of CO2 equivalent emissions.
E-methanol and e-ammonia are produced from hydrogen via electrolysis powered by renewables, with minimal tweaks required for existing dual-fuel engines.

articles.title: Too much to choose from, too little to decide
articles.summary: The article discusses the challenges of finding the perfect balance between price, quality, and reliability in power and energy systems, particularly in the solar and storage sectors. Despite advancements in technology, low-cost solutions often dominate the market, leading to concerns about long-term success and durability. As a result, manufacturers must carefully consider their product designs to ensure they meet the needs of operators.
key_takeaways: The market pressure in the solar and storage sectors favors low-cost solutions, which can lead to compromises on quality and reliability.
To achieve long-term success, manufacturers should prioritize higher-quality materials and more durable electronic components, especially for inverters and batteries.
The sustained decline in market prices has created intense pressure to cut costs and optimize products, which can result in units being packed into a single container to reduce shipping costs.

articles.title: Hydrogen Production Trends Rise as Doosan Enerbility Secures US Data Center Gas Turbine Contracts
articles.summary: Doosan Enerbility has secured contracts to supply three 380 MW-class natural gas turbines to power a US data center, marking its first export of large machines designed for self-generation. This deal follows another award in October, bringing Doosan's US backlog to five turbines. The move is seen as part of the growing trend towards on-site self-generation at data centers to address grid limitations and rising kilowatt-hour prices.
key_takeaways: Data center power needs are increasing, with most new capacity in the US leaning on natural gas rather than renewable energy sources, due to the limitations of pure green energy.
The use of natural gas turbines for on-site self-generation at data centers allows companies to sidestep transmission snarls and lock in more predictable costs.
Doosan Enerbility is positioning itself as a partner for modular and scalable power solutions, backed by its nuclear pedigree and extensive testing hours.

articles.title: Coal India starts accepting bids for 20 MW floating solar plant
articles.summary: Coal India Ltd. is inviting bids to develop a 20 MW floating solar facility at Chilwa Taal in Gorakhpur district, Uttar Pradesh, India. The project aims to optimize water-body use and reduce land requirements while expanding the company's renewable energy portfolio. The selected contractor will operate and maintain the plant for five years after commissioning.
key_takeaways: Coal India is developing a 20 MW floating solar photovoltaic project in Gorakhpur, Uttar Pradesh, which will utilize floating solar technology to optimize water-body use and reduce land requirements.
The project scope includes design, engineering, procurement, construction, installation, testing, commissioning, and ongoing operation and maintenance for five years after commissioning.
Bidding for the project is currently open, with a deadline of January 14, 2026, and the selected contractor will operate and maintain the plant to expand Coal India's renewable energy portfolio.

articles.title: Hungary to host 450 MW solar plant using back-contact modules
articles.summary: The article reports on a 450 MW solar power plant project in northern Hungary, which will be the country's largest PV facility. The project is expected to generate approximately 470 GWh of electricity per year and reduce carbon dioxide emissions by around 415,000 metric tons annually. Solarpro, a Europe-based engineering company, is deploying nearly 700,000 Longi solar modules for the project.
key_takeaways: The 450 MW solar power plant in Hungary will be the country's largest PV facility and one of the largest in Europe.
The project will generate approximately 470 GWh of electricity per year, enough to supply around 106,000 households, and reduce carbon dioxide emissions by about 415,000 metric tons annually.

The solar panels used in the project are Longi modules with back-contact technology, which aims to improve efficiency, reduce microcracking, and support stable long-term performance under various environmental conditions.

articles.title: Techno-Economic Case Study of a Rural Local Electricity Community in Switzerland
articles.summary: The article examines the techno-economic implications of Local Electricity Communities (CELs) in rural Switzerland, exploring how CELs can enhance renewable energy use and offer financial gains. The study found that larger and more heterogeneous communities achieve better internal matching of supply and demand, but the overall incentive remains limited due to tariff design. CELs also reduce grid imports for Distribution System Operators (DSOs), leading to a reduction in distribution tariff revenues.
key_takeaways: CELs can enhance local renewable energy use, particularly photovoltaics, and offer modest financial gains, with outcomes influenced by community size, composition, and tariff design.
Larger and more heterogeneous communities tend to achieve better internal matching of supply and demand through CELs, but the overall incentive is limited due to tariff structure.
CELs reduce grid imports for DSOs, resulting in a substantial reduction in distribution tariff revenues, requiring regulatory adaptation.

articles.title: Linear Attention for Joint Power Optimization and User-Centric Clustering in Cell-Free Networks
articles.summary: This article proposes a novel transformer model that jointly optimizes AP clustering and power allocation in cell-free networks, leveraging spatial coordinates of user devices and APs. The model is designed to be lightweight, flexible, and scalable, overcoming limitations of existing deep learning approaches in handling dynamic network configurations and pilot contamination.
key_takeaways: The proposed model addresses the limitations of existing deep learning models by jointly predicting AP clusters and powers from spatial coordinates, without requiring channel estimation overhead.
The model incorporates a customized linear attention mechanism to capture user-AP interactions efficiently, enabling linear scalability with respect to the number of users.

The numerical results confirm the model's effectiveness in maximizing minimum spectral efficiency and providing near-optimal performance while ensuring adaptability and scalability in dynamic scenarios.

articles.title: Cooperative Energy Scheduling of Multi-Microgrids Based on Risk-Sensitive Reinforcement Learning
articles.summary: The article proposes a risk-sensitive reinforcement learning framework with shared memory (RRL-SM) for multi-microgrid scheduling, addressing the challenges of obscured credit assignment and inefficient communication in current methods. The proposed approach leverages distributional modeling and attention-based representations to quantify the relationship between individual and joint risk values, enabling aligned local decisions with global risk objectives. Simulation results demonstrate a favorable balance between reliability and economic performance.
key_takeaways: The article proposes a novel reinforcement learning framework (RRL-SM) for multi-microgrid scheduling that addresses challenges of current methods, including obscured credit assignment and inefficient communication.

The proposed approach uses distributional modeling and attention-based representations to quantify the relationship between individual and joint risk values, enabling aligned local decisions with global risk objectives.
Simulation results show that RRL-SM reduces load-shedding risk by 84.5%, demonstrating a favorable balance between reliability and economic performance in multi-microgrid scheduling.

articles.title: Dispatch-Aware Learning for Optimal Transmission Switching
articles.summary: The article proposes a dispatch-aware deep neural network (DA-DNN) to accelerate optimal transmission switching (OTS), which improves optimal power flow (OPF) by selectively opening transmission lines. The proposed method uses a DC-OPF layer and achieves stable learning through customized weight-bias initialization, enabling it to produce feasible topologies and dispatch pairs in the same time as solving the DCOPF. This approach captures the economic advantages of OTS while maintaining scalability and generalization ability.
key_takeaways: The proposed DA-DNN accelerates DC-OTS without relying on pre-solved labels, addressing the computational complexity issue associated with optimal power flow.
The embedded differentiable DC-OPF layer ensures that all physical network constraints are enforced throughout training and inference, maintaining the integrity of the optimization process.

The customized weight-bias initialization enables stable learning from the first iteration, allowing the DA-DNN to produce feasible topologies and dispatch pairs in a comparable time frame to solving the DCOPF.

articles.title: Layer-to-layer Closed-loop Switched Heating and Cooling Control of the Laser Powder Bed Fusion Process
articles.summary: The article discusses a novel controller for the laser powder bed fusion process, which stabilizes interlayer temperature through closed-loop feedback control. The controller measures interlayer temperature using a thermal camera and adjusts laser power to maintain a preset reference temperature. The study evaluates the performance of the controller in supported and unsupported overhanging parts, highlighting its effectiveness in controlling interlayer temperature.
key_takeaways: The proposed controller is effective in stabilizing interlayer temperature across varying cross-sectional areas while remaining within the material's stable processing zone.

The controller's performance depends on the support structure used during build, with supported parts exhibiting reduced overheating but higher energy and material consumption, while unsupported parts have faster build times due to increased dwell time assignments.
The introduction of interlayer dwell time offers a practical solution for maintaining thermal stability in complex geometries prone to excessive thermal stresses.

articles.title: N.Y., Ontario Collaborating on Nuclear Power Development
articles.summary: New York Governor Kathy Hochul and Ontario Premier Doug Ford have collaborated on a memorandum of understanding to develop nuclear power generation. The agreement aims to share information, resources, and institutional knowledge to support advanced nuclear development between the two provinces. This move is part of both governments' efforts to increase nuclear power capacity in their respective energy strategies.
key_takeaways: New York and Ontario are teaming up to develop nuclear power generation, with a focus on sharing information, resources, and expertise to support advanced nuclear development.
The agreement builds upon the existing collaboration between the two provinces on hydropower generation plants on the Niagara and St. Lawrence rivers, which form part of their shared border.

The partnership is significant, given that New York has begun developing at least a gigawatt of advanced nuclear capacity, while Ontario is under construction with its first small modular reactor and plans for three more nearby.

articles.title: Trump Media—TAE Merger: Fusion’s Public Market Leap
articles.summary: The article reports on the merger between Trump Media and TAE, a fusion energy company, marking a significant milestone in the fusion industry. The merger is expected to propel Fusion's public market presence forward. While details about the specifics of the merger are not provided, the development suggests a notable advancement in the field.
key_takeaways: The merger between Trump Media and TAE indicates a significant partnership or collaboration in the fusion energy sector.
Fusion energy has achieved a major milestone with this merger, which goes beyond scientific advancements to also impact public market presence.
This development could potentially herald new opportunities or growth prospects for companies involved in the field of fusion energy.

articles.title: CAISO Readies EDAM Tariff Changes as New Market Nears Opening
articles.summary: The California Independent System Operator (CAISO) is preparing to submit proposed tariff changes to the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) in early 2026, with the goal of facilitating a smooth transition to its new Extended Day-Ahead Market (EDAM). The proposed revisions aim to improve market design and reduce phantom congestion. CAISO's EDAM system is set to open in May 2026.
key_takeaways: CAISO is proposing tariff changes to help ease participants into the ISO's new EDAM, including formatting changes and rule adjustments that affect overall market design.

The proposed revisions include a change from modeling intertie resources at specific scheduling points to generation aggregation points (GAPs), which could improve power flow and market accuracy but also raise concerns about multiple prices for the same intertie.
CAISO's EDAM system is set to open in May 2026, and the proposed tariff changes are intended to keep this timeline on track.

articles.title: Norwegian towns take stakes in nuclear project company
articles.summary: The municipalities of Lyngdal and Farsund in southern Norway's Lister region have decided to become co-owners of Lister Kjernekraft AS, a nuclear power plant project development company. This partnership aims to develop the Lister kraftverk, a nuclear power plant project located in the same region. The move reflects growing interest in nuclear energy in Norway.
key_takeaways: Norwegian municipalities are taking an active role in developing nuclear projects, indicating a shift towards a more decentralized approach to energy production.
The partnership between Lyngdal and Farsund municipalities and Lister Kjernekraft AS may lead to increased local control and decision-making over the development of nuclear power plants in Norway.

This development could potentially boost the country's nuclear energy sector, which has been facing challenges in recent years due to declining demand and increasing competition from renewable energy sources.

articles.title: Hydrogen Fuel Cells Propel China’s Tianmushan-1 Drone to Guinness Record Flight
articles.summary: Researchers at Beihang University's Tianmushan Laboratory have developed a hydrogen fuel cell-powered drone, Tianmushan-1, which broke the Guinness Record for the longest distance flown by a hydrogen-powered drone. The drone completed a 188.605 km flight in four hours without touching down or switching batteries, showcasing the potential of green hydrogen and zero-emission technology. This achievement demonstrates the feasibility of using hydrogen fuel cells to power drones for long-endurance missions.
key_takeaways: Hydrogen fuel cell technology has been successfully integrated into a drone, enabling it to complete a record-breaking 188.605 km flight without battery swap or emergency landing.
The use of hydrogen fuel cells in drones offers potential for longer-endurance missions and more efficient power delivery compared to traditional battery-powered systems.
This achievement demonstrates the feasibility of green hydrogen and zero-emission technology in drone applications, paving the way for future development and expansion in this field.

articles.title: X-energy 'reserves' Doosan forgings
articles.summary: X-energy, a US-based developer of small modular reactors, has signed an agreement with Doosan Enerbility, a South Korean nuclear component designer and manufacturer, to secure key components for its Xe-100 high temperature gas-cooled reactor. This partnership is significant as it supports the growth of X-energy's Xe-100 reactor in the global market. The collaboration will likely lead to increased efficiency and reduced costs for X-energy.
key_takeaways: X-energy has partnered with Doosan Enerbility to obtain key components for its Xe-100 high temperature gas-cooled small modular reactor, supporting the development of this technology.
This partnership is a significant step forward for X-energy's global expansion and growth in the nuclear energy sector.
The collaboration between X-energy and Doosan Enerbility aims to increase efficiency and reduce costs for X-energy's reactors, making them more competitive in the market.

articles.title: UK aims for cancer treatments from reprocessed uranium
articles.summary: The UK is working towards developing cancer treatments using reprocessed uranium, with a 15-year agreement between the Nuclear Decommissioning Authority and Bicycle Therapeutics. The goal is to secure the medical isotope lead-212 from the UK's stockpile of reprocessed nuclear fuel. This partnership aims to provide access to this vital isotope for medical research and treatment.
key_takeaways: The UK has secured a 15-year agreement with Bicycle Therapeutics to develop cancer treatments using reprocessed uranium, specifically targeting the production of lead-212.
The use of reprocessed uranium in medicine could provide a new source of supply for the medical isotope lead-212, addressing potential shortages and ensuring continued access for patients.

This partnership demonstrates the UK's commitment to exploring alternative nuclear fuel sources for medical applications, reducing reliance on traditional nuclear power and promoting sustainable healthcare solutions.

articles.title: Akaysha Energy enters 300MWh BESS into NEM trading in Queensland, Australia
articles.summary: Akaysha Energy has successfully commissioned the first phase of its Ulinda Park Battery Energy Storage System (BESS) project in Queensland, Australia. The 300MWh BESS is being used for NEM trading, indicating its ability to provide frequency response services to the grid. This development marks an important milestone for the Waratah Super Battery project.
key_takeaways: Akaysha Energy has successfully commissioned a 300MWh Battery Energy Storage System (BESS) in Queensland, Australia.
The BESS is being used for NEM trading, suggesting it can provide frequency response services to support grid stability.
This development represents an important milestone for the Waratah Super Battery project, indicating progress towards its full operational capacity.

articles.title: India's atomic energy bill tabled in parliament
articles.summary: The Indian government has tabled a bill in the parliament that proposes a new legal framework for India's nuclear sector, marking an important step towards regulating and developing the country's atomic energy industry.
key_takeaways: The bill is expected to provide a new legislative framework for India's nuclear sector, aiming to regulate and develop the country's atomic energy industry.
The move is seen as a significant step towards promoting nuclear power in India, with the aim of increasing electricity generation from nuclear sources.
The proposed legal framework is likely to cover various aspects of nuclear regulation, including safety, security, and environmental impact assessments.

articles.title: It’s A Heckuva Good Time To Launch A New EV In The US, Says Faraday Future
articles.summary: The article discusses the launch of a new electric vehicle (EV) by Faraday Future Intelligent Electric Inc. in the US market, highlighting a promising time for EVs despite industry concerns.
key_takeaways: A new EV from Faraday Future is set to enter the US market, providing a positive development for the electric vehicle industry.
The launch of this new EV coincides with an uncertain future for the industry due to ongoing challenges and concerns.
Despite these uncertainties, Faraday Future's new entry indicates a continued interest in electric vehicles in the US market.

articles.title: Maryland Governor Issues Executive Order on Affordability and Reliability
articles.summary: Maryland Governor Wes Moore has issued an executive order to address the state's energy affordability and reliability issues, following a recent capacity auction by PJM that fell short of its reserve margin target. The order aims to optimize permitting processes and facilitate the deployment of shovel-ready projects to close the projected capacity gap. This move is part of the governor's effort to make energy policy more personal and affordable for Marylanders.
key_takeaways: The executive order, "Building an Affordable and Reliable Energy Future," seeks to address the projected capacity gap in Maryland's energy system by optimizing permitting processes and facilitating the deployment of shovel-ready projects.
The order creates a new "Energy Subcabinet" chaired by the director of the Maryland Energy Administration, with members from cabinet agencies, to oversee the implementation of the plan.
Governor Moore emphasizes that this effort is part of his administration's commitment to making energy policy more personal and affordable for Marylanders, rather than just benefiting companies.

articles.title: Podcast: We bought 2 new EVs, Tesla Robotaxi, Ford’s $19B EV charge, and more
articles.summary: The Electrek Podcast discusses recent news in sustainable transport and energy, including the hosts' personal experiences with new electric vehicles (EVs), updates on Tesla's Robotaxi service, and a significant investment by Ford in EV technology.
key_takeaways: The hosts of the podcast each purchased a new EV, likely Tesla models given the mention of Tesla Robotaxi.
Ford has made a substantial investment of $19 billion in electric vehicle (EV) technology, highlighting the company's commitment to expanding its EV offerings.
Tesla's Robotaxi service is mentioned as part of the discussion, but specific details about its progress are not provided in this summary.

articles.title: Dodge adds NACS charging to the 2027 Charger Daytona EV, but it’s still pretty pricey
articles.summary: The article reports that Dodge has added NACS (North American Charging Standard) charging to the 2027 Charger Daytona Scat Pack EV, which is billed as the "world's quickest and most powerful muscle car." However, despite this new feature, the EV remains pricey. The exact price is not mentioned in the provided content.
key_takeaways: Dodge has added NACS charging to the 2027 Charger Daytona Scat Pack EV, providing a convenient charging option for customers.
Despite the addition of NACS charging, the 2027 Charger Daytona Scat Pack EV remains a premium product with an unspecified price point.
The article suggests that the EV's high performance capabilities and new features may not justify its full price, leaving room for speculation about the exact cost.

articles.title: Sarawak Metro Awards Linde EOX KUTS Plant Upgrade
articles.summary: The Sarawak Metro has signed a contract with Linde EOX to upgrade the Kuching Urban Transportation System's (KUTS) hydrogen plant in Malaysia. The upgrade aims to boost conversion efficiency, cut CO₂ emissions, and support the region's transition to sustainable energy. The project is part of Malaysia's 2050 net-zero vision and could spark investments and cross-border trade across ASEAN.
key_takeaways: The KUTS plant will be upgraded to improve hydrogen production efficiency and reduce CO₂ emissions.
The upgrade includes the installation of future carbon capture modules to support the production of blue hydrogen, in line with Malaysia's 2050 net-zero vision.
The project is a significant investment in sustainable energy for the region, with a contract value of approximately RM58 million.
The upgrade is part of Sarawak Metro and Linde EOX's efforts to build out hydrogen infrastructure in Asia, which could lead to more investments and cross-border trade across ASEAN.

articles.title: Volkswagen boss declares the end of small gas cars, urging the future is electric
articles.summary: Volkswagen's CEO, Thomas Schäfer, has declared that small gas cars are no longer viable and that the future lies in electric vehicles (EVs). This declaration is part of Volkswagen's strategy to transition to a more sustainable and eco-friendly transportation sector. The company plans to introduce a new family of smaller, more affordable EVs.
key_takeaways: Volkswagen will not offer small gas-powered cars in its upcoming family of smaller, more affordable EVs.
Thomas Schäfer believes that the future of the "small-gas-car segment" is electric, indicating a shift towards sustainable and eco-friendly transportation options.
The company's strategy aims to transition away from internal combustion engines and towards cleaner, more environmentally friendly energy sources.

articles.title: A Tale Of Two Michigans — Solar vs. Data Center Battle Intensifies
articles.summary: A proposed solar farm to power an Oracle data center in rural Michigan has been defeated, with local residents celebrating the victory. The project was likely met with resistance from environmental and community groups concerned about the impact of large-scale data centers on local ecosystems and economies. However, the article does not provide further details on the specifics of the defeat or the motivations behind it.
key_takeaways: A proposed solar farm to power an Oracle data center in rural Michigan has been defeated by local residents.
The project's defeat is likely due to environmental and community concerns about the impact of large-scale data centers.
The article does not provide further details on the specifics of the defeat or the motivations behind it.

articles.title: Supported By Big Oil, Data Center Boom Faces Growing Local Opposition
articles.summary: The growth of data centers is being driven by big oil companies seeking new revenue streams, but this boom is facing increasing local opposition due to concerns over energy consumption and environmental impact. Fossil fuel companies' promises about powering data centers are not always sustainable, raising questions about the sustainability of this trend. As a result, communities are pushing back against data center development.
key_takeaways: The expansion of data centers is being driven by big oil companies looking to diversify their revenue streams and increase energy demand.
Local opposition to data center development is growing due to concerns over energy consumption, environmental impact, and the unsustainable nature of fossil fuel-based operations.
Communities are pushing back against data center development, citing potential negative consequences for local ecosystems, air quality, and public health.

articles.title: Georgia’s lame-duck utility commission OKs massive, pricey gas buildout
articles.summary: The Georgia Public Service Commission has approved a massive and pricey gas buildout plan by the state's biggest utility, allowing for one of the largest new fossil-fuel investments in the country. Critics fear that this move will lead to increased utility bills for most Georgia residents over the coming years. The approval was made in a last-minute decision.
key_takeaways: The approved plan involves a significant investment in gas infrastructure, which critics argue will contribute to higher energy costs for consumers.
The state's largest utility is expected to commence one of the largest new fossil-fuel buildouts in the country, raising concerns about environmental impact and public health.

The decision was made by the Georgia Public Service Commission without sufficient public input or consideration for alternative energy sources, sparking criticism from environmental and consumer advocacy groups.

articles.title: Slovak researchers predict PV inverter output without weather sensors
articles.summary: Researchers in Slovakia have developed a machine-learning framework that predicts PV inverter output and detects anomalies using only electrical and temporal data, achieving 100% accuracy in classifying inverter output states under static operating conditions. The model uses real-world operational data from a grid-connected PV plant and eliminates the need for environmental sensors such as irradiance or temperature data. This innovative approach has significant implications for practical PV monitoring deployments.
key_takeaways: Researchers have developed a machine-learning framework that predicts PV inverter output and detects anomalies using only electrical and temporal data, achieving 100% accuracy under static operating conditions.
The model uses real-world operational data from a grid-connected PV plant, eliminating the need for environmental sensors such as irradiance or temperature data.
The approach utilizes time-based proxies to capture cyclical solar generation behavior, addressing the absence of irradiance or temperature data and enabling practical PV monitoring deployments.

articles.title: Another EV battery swapping company is going bankrupt
articles.summary: A company that claimed to revolutionize the EV battery swapping industry has gone bankrupt, highlighting the challenges and uncertainties of scaling up such a complex technology.
key_takeaways: The bankruptcy of another EV battery swapping company underscores the difficulties in deploying this technology on a large scale, despite its promise to accelerate adoption of electric vehicles.
The failure of these companies suggests that the development and implementation of EV battery swapping stations require significant investment, technical expertise, and market demand.
This trend raises questions about the viability of EV battery swapping as a sustainable business model, particularly in the face of increasing competition from traditional charging infrastructure.

articles.title: House passes permitting reform bill with anti-offshore wind amendment
articles.summary: A permitting reform bill was passed by the House, including an amendment that restricts offshore wind projects. The amendment is seen as critical for preserving the Trump administration's ability to review ocean wind projects. Rep. Chris Smith stated that this amendment was "absolutely critical" for maintaining this aspect of the administration's policies.
key_takeaways: A permitting reform bill with an anti-offshore wind amendment has been passed by the House, suggesting a shift in policy priorities.
The inclusion of an offshore wind restriction is seen as a setback for renewable energy development, particularly ocean wind projects.
This development may have implications for the Trump administration's policies on environmental issues and its ability to review and approve or reject certain projects.

articles.title: Tracks of low-pressure systems split Europe’s solar performance in November
articles.summary: The article reports on a strong east-west split in Europe's solar performance in November, with Eastern Europe experiencing lower-than-normal irradiance due to persistent storms and flooding. In contrast, Western and Central Europe enjoyed clearer skies under higher pressure, leading to above-average solar generation levels. The Atlantic coast was an exception, where Storm Claudia reduced irradiance to near or below average.
key_takeaways: Eastern Europe experienced 15-20% below-normal irradiance in November due to persistent storms and flooding.
Western and Central Europe saw 15-20% above-average solar generation levels under clearer skies and higher pressure systems.
The Atlantic coast was particularly affected by Storm Claudia, which reduced irradiance to near or below average in Portugal, the British Isles, and parts of France and Spain.

articles.title: India passes 132.8 GW of installed solar capacity
articles.summary: India has reached a milestone of 132.8 GW of installed solar capacity as of November 2025, driven by utility-scale projects in Rajasthan, Gujarat, and Maharashtra. The central government has expanded initiatives to accelerate decentralized solar deployment, including the PM Surya Ghar: Muft Bijli Yojana program. This growth is expected to continue with the target of installing rooftop solar at one crore residential households nationwide.
key_takeaways: India's installed solar capacity reached 132.85 GW as of November 2025, with utility-scale projects accounting for most capacity additions.
The three states of Rajasthan, Gujarat, and Maharashtra together accounted for more than 58% of the national total, with Rajasthan leading with around 36 GW of cumulative solar installations.
Initiatives such as PM Surya Ghar: Muft Bijli Yojana aim to accelerate decentralized solar deployment by targeting rooftop solar installations at residential households nationwide.

articles.title: New England Coordinated Procurement Nets 173 MW of New Solar
articles.summary: The article reports that representatives of Connecticut, Maine, Massachusetts, and Vermont have selected 173 MW of new solar generation through a coordinated procurement process. The expedited process aimed to procure "advanced-stage projects" that could take advantage of expiring federal clean energy tax credits. All selected projects are expected to be in service by the end of 2030.
key_takeaways: The coordinated procurement process resulted in the selection of 173 MW of new solar generation across four states, highlighting increased collaboration among New England states to procure clean energy.

The expedited process was specifically aimed at procuring "advanced-stage projects" that could benefit from expiring federal clean energy tax credits, which is expected to drive innovation and efficiency in the renewable energy sector.
The selected projects are expected to be operational by the end of 2030, contributing to the region's transition towards cleaner energy sources and reducing greenhouse gas emissions.

articles.title: MG begins deliveries of the world’s first mass-produced EV with a semi-solid-state battery
articles.summary: SAIC MG has begun delivering the first mass-produced electric vehicles (EVs) in China, featuring a semi-solid-state battery. The EV model, MG4, starts at under $15,000. This marks an important milestone for the adoption of semi-solid-state batteries in mass production.
key_takeaways: SAIC MG has successfully launched the world's first mass-produced electric vehicle with a semi-solid-state battery.
The MG4 model is priced competitively, starting at under $15,000, making it an attractive option for budget-conscious consumers.
The introduction of semi-solid-state batteries in mass production could potentially accelerate the transition to sustainable energy solutions and reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

articles.title: India's Lok Sabha passes SHANTI atomic energy bill
articles.summary: The Lok Sabha, India's lower house of parliament, has passed the SHANTI atomic energy bill, which establishes a new legal framework for India's nuclear sector. The bill allows for private sector participation and marks an important step towards developing India's nuclear capabilities. Discussions are now underway in the upper house.
key_takeaways: The passage of the SHANTI atomic energy bill paves the way for increased private sector involvement in India's nuclear sector, potentially leading to new investments and technological advancements.
The bill establishes a new legal framework for India's nuclear sector, providing clarity on regulations and governance structures.
The development of India's nuclear capabilities is seen as an important step towards enhancing the country's energy security and contributing to its economic growth.

articles.title: ‘Evolving revenue mix, harsh Nordic operating conditions’: Hitachi Energy supplies PCS to Finland’s largest BESS
articles.summary: Hitachi Energy has supplied a Power Conversion System (PCS) to Finland's largest Battery Energy Storage System (BESS), which will need to navigate "especially challenging" operating conditions and evolving grid code requirements. The BESS is designed to play a crucial role in the country's energy system, particularly as the revenue mix of renewable energy sources shifts. This project highlights Hitachi Energy's ability to supply critical infrastructure for the growing demand for energy storage.
key_takeaways: Finland's largest BESS will require specialized equipment to cope with harsh Nordic operating conditions, such as extreme temperatures and limited daylight hours.
The grid code requirements in Finland are stringent, indicating a need for reliable and efficient energy storage systems that can adapt to changing energy demands.
The project showcases Hitachi Energy's expertise in supplying PCS solutions for large-scale BESS projects, which is essential for the growing adoption of renewable energy sources.

articles.title: Machine Learning-based Optimal Control for Colloidal Self-Assembly
articles.summary: The article discusses a machine learning-based approach to control colloidal self-assembly into specific patterns, overcoming the challenges of complex process dynamics. A new framework combining unsupervised learning and graph convolutional neural work for state observation with deep reinforcement learning-based optimal control policy calculation is proposed. The method demonstrates superior performance in achieving ordered 2-dimensional spherical colloidal self-assembly.
key_takeaways: The article introduces a machine learning-based approach to control colloidal self-assembly, which shows promise in achieving precise control over complex process dynamics.

The proposed framework combines unsupervised learning and graph convolutional neural work for state observation with deep reinforcement learning-based optimal control policy calculation, providing a data-driven control approach.
The method achieves an actual success rate of 97% in obtaining ordered 2-dimensional spherical colloidal self-assembly in an electric field-mediated system.

articles.title: Closed Loop Reference Optimization for Extrusion Additive Manufacturing
articles.summary: The article proposes a closed-loop optimization method for additive manufacturing, specifically extrusion-based processes, to improve the tracking performance and response time of the material width. The proposed LQR controller with force feedback is used to track the extruded filament's width accurately, while also accounting for machine constraints and generating optimal references. Simulation results demonstrate significant improvements in tracking accuracy and response time compared to traditional methods.
key_takeaways: The proposed LQR controller with force feedback improves tracking performance of the material width during extrusion additive manufacturing processes.
Preemptive optimization of the reference force generates optimal references that account for machine constraints, leading to improved closed-loop dynamics and reduced errors.

Experimental results on a Fused Filament Fabrication 3D printer demonstrate a significant reduction in root mean square error (39.57%) and settling time (83.7%) compared to traditional tracking methods.

articles.title: Lyapunov-based Adaptive Transformer (LyAT) for Control of Stochastic Nonlinear Systems
articles.summary: The article presents a novel Lyapunov-based Adaptive Transformer (LyAT) controller for stochastic nonlinear systems, addressing the limitations of existing transformer-based approaches in adaptive control. The developed continuous LyAT controller adaptively estimates drift and diffusion uncertainties without requiring offline pre-training, providing real-time weight updates while guaranteeing stability assurances. Experimental validation on a quadrotor demonstrates the performance of the developed controller.
key_takeaways: Traditional transformer-based controllers lack real-time adaptation capabilities and stability assurances due to their reliance on offline training with fixed weights.

The LyAT controller overcomes these limitations by developing an analytically derived adaptation law that enables real-time weight updates while guaranteeing probabilistic uniform ultimate boundedness of tracking and parameter estimation errors.
The proposed approach provides a solution for adaptive control in stochastic nonlinear systems, offering a promising direction for future research in control applications.

articles.title: A Comprehensive Benchmark Platform for Process Control Research of Outdoor Microalgae Raceway Reactors

The goal is to bridge control methodology and outdoor algal bioprocess engineering, enabling the development of multivariable control strategies for disturbance-rich environmental systems.
key_takeaways: The platform evaluates process control strategies in outdoor microalgae raceway reactors by integrating four key control regulation tasks: pH, dissolved oxygen (DO), culture volume, and temperature.

A high-fidelity dynamic model and closed-loop simulation environment are used to capture the strongly coupled thermal, physicochemical, and biological processes governing industrial-scale open raceway ponds.
The platform provides a unified global performance index, as well as individual metrics for each control problem, enabling consistent and quantitative comparison of alternative control strategies.

articles.title: Operator-Theoretic Joint Estimation of Aging-Aware State of Charge and Control-Informed State of Health

The framework combines a Koopman-based latent dynamics model with a neural operator to predict discharge capacity and estimate state of charge, ensuring stability through spectral-radius clipping. The method is trained end-to-end and demonstrates real-time capability while handling condition shifts and unseen regimes.
key_takeaways: The proposed framework integrates a Koopman-based latent dynamics model with a neural operator to jointly estimate aging-aware state of charge and control-informed state of health.
The method ensures stability through spectral-radius clipping of the Koopman operator, allowing for accurate and real-time capacity forecasts.
The framework demonstrates robustness to condition shifts and unseen regimes, utilizing zero-shot and few-shot out-of-distribution adaptation mechanisms.

key_takeaways: Most existing research on resilience focuses on lower levels of uncertainty and rarely considers both dynamic complexity and deep uncertainty simultaneously.
Current approaches to assessing resilience are limited by their inability to effectively address the interconnectedness and unpredictability of coupled systems under complex and uncertain conditions.

The study proposes a conceptual framework and practical tools to support more comprehensive and effective resilience assessments, which could be beneficial for addressing global challenges such as climate change and pandemics.
